article:
'Earnings' are the net benefits of a corporation's operation. Robert G.
Eccles, Robert H. Herz, E. Mary Keegan, David M. H. Phillips: The Value
Reporting Revolution: Moving Beyond the Earnings Game; Price-Waterhouse-Coopers,
2001. Earnings is also the amount on which corporate tax is due. For an
analysis of specific aspects of corporate operations several more specific terms
are used as EBIT -- earnings before interest and taxes, EBITDA - earnings before
interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization.

Many alternative terms for earnings are in common use, such as income and
profit. These terms in turn have a variety of definitions, depending on their
context and the objectives of the authors. For instance, the IRS uses the term
profit to describe earnings, whereas for the corporation the profit it reports
is the amount left after taxes are taken out. Many economic discussions use
principles derived from Karl Marx Karl Marx: Das Kapital, Kritik der
Politischen Oekonmie; 1967. and Adam Smith. Adam Smith: The Wealth of
Nations; 1876. However the rise of the importance of intellectual capital
Gordon Smith and Russell Parr: Intellectual Property, 4th edition; Wiley
2005. affects such analyses.
